title: Dow tumbles over 600 points as omicron fears ignite fresh selling to start Christmas week trade
text:
How are stock indexes trading?

The S&P 500 SPX traded 82 points, or 1.8%, lower to 4,538.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA fell 650 points, or 1.8%, to around 34,713, weighed by losses in Goldman SachsGS, UnitedHealth Group Inc.UNH and Caterpillar Inc. CAT

The Nasdaq Composite Index COMP declined 286 points, or 1.9%, to reach 14,883, putting the tech-heavy index about 7% below its Nov. 19 record close.

On Friday, the Dow dropped more than 500 points, or 1.5%, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite following it lower. For the week, the Dow lost 1.7%, the S&P 500 dropped 1.9% and the Nasdaq tumbled 3%.

What's driving the markets?

Markets were slumping in the start to an abbreviated week of trading for most financial markets in observance of Christmas. All 11 sectors of the S&P 500 were trading in negative territory, lead by sharp declines in financialsXX:SP500.40, energyXX:SP500.10 and materialsXX:SP500.15 as crude prices plunged.

Worries about omicron have sapped some of the joy out of the market for bullish investors, with lockdowns in parts of Europe weighing on sentiment.

News that President Joe Biden's signature $2 trillion spending plan appeared doomed also was being greeted with selling. Sen. Joe Manchin, D-W.Va., said on Sunday that he cannot support it—potentially handing Biden and Democrats a major political loss.

Prompted by the political wrangling, Goldman Sachs downgraded their U.S. growth forecasts for 2022, citing difficulties in getting the spending bill passed.

Last week's losses came as investors weighed the Federal Reserve's hawkish pivot, speeding up its reduction of monthly bond purchases and predicting three interest-rate hikes next year.

“With flight to safety being the overriding concern, lower bond yields are questioning the FOMC's ability to act as hawkish as they signaled last week. Markets are being challenged by a range of uncertainties at a time where thinner trading volumes ahead of the holiday period can exacerbate price swings,” said John Hardy, head of FX strategy at Saxo Bank, in a note to clients.

Stock futures appeared to pare losses slightly after Moderna MRNA said its COVID-19 booster, when combined with two vaccines, offers 37-fold protection against the omicron variant.

That's as new COVID-19 cases are growing sharply in many parts of the world, fueled by the rapid spread of that variant. Dr. Anthony Fauci said Sunday that he expects record cases of COVID-19 this winter, and urged people to get vaccinated and get boosters. The Netherlands began a lockdown that will last until mid-January and the U.K. hasn't ruled out tighter pre-Christmas restrictions.

The World Economic Forum announced that its Davos meeting, which was due to be held in January, will be delayed to summer 2022, due to the spread of COVID-19. It's the second straight year that the conference has been postponed.

Selling of perceived riskier assets extended to oil prices, which fell sharply on concerns of a growing hit to the global economy. Front-month West Texas intermediate crude CL. 1 fell 4.8% to $67.43 a barrel, while Brent crude BRN00, the global benchmark, lost 4.1% to $70.48 a barrel.

On the data front, U.S. leading economic index rose a sharp 1.1% in November, the Conference Board said Monday. Economists polled by The Wall Street Journal had expected a 0.9% gain. Over the last six months, the index is up 4.6%.

The increase signals the economy will continue to expand in the first half of 2022 although the resurgence of COVID-19, inflation and supply-chain disruptions remain risks, said Ataman Ozyildirim, senior director of economic research at the Conference Board. 

Which companies are in focus?

Oracle Corp. ORCL confirmed on Monday a deal to acquire electronic-medical-records company Cerner Corp. CERN for more than $30 billion in cash. Shares are down 3%, while Cerner shares were up by about 1%.

Shares of BP Midstream PartnersBPMP surged 13% after energy giant BP said it has entered into a definitive agreement to buy the master limited partnership in an all stock-deal.

Novavax shares NVAX were down nearly 2%, even as the European Medicines Agency recommended granting Emergency Use Authorization for its COVID-19 vaccine.

ModernaMRNA shares fell 1.4% after the pharmaceutical group said a booster shot of its COVID-19 vaccine provided 37-fold protection against the omicron variant when combined with two vaccine shots.

BiogenBIIB shares slipped 0.7%, as the biotechnology company said it would cut the price of its Alzheimer's drug aduhlem by 50% starting Jan. 1 to about $28,200 a year

Bluebird BioBLUE shares tumbled nearly 18% after the company announced a partial clinical hold for patients under 18 in sickle cell gene therapy program

How are other assets trading?

The yield on the 10-year Treasury note BX:TMUBMUSD10Y fell about 2 basis points to 1.391%, according to Dow Jones Market Data. Treasury yields and prices move in opposite directions.

The ICE U.S. Dollar Index DXY, a measure of the currency against a half-dozen other monetary units, was down under 0.2%.

Gold futures GC00 for February delivery GCG22 fell 0.5% to trade at $1,795.10 an ounce.

The Stoxx Europe 600 Index XX:SXXP closed 1.4% lower, while London's FTSE 100 index UK:UKX fell 1%.

In Asia, the Shanghai Composite Index CN:SHCOMP lost 1%, the Hang Seng Index HK:HSI fell 1.9% in Hong Kong, China's CSI 300 XX:000300 skidded 1.5% lower and Japan's Nikkei 225 Index JP:NIK dropped 2.1%.
